ygData.subject: Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, we do need to add to Picbreeder a display of genome complexity for each image.  That would certainly answer some questions.  I am going to see if we can

Peter, we do need to add to Picbreeder a display of genome complexity
for e=
ach image.  That would certainly answer some questions.  I am
going to see =
if we can get that working soon.  

In any case, part of the theory behind =
CPPNs is that they should end
up being more compact representations than ce=
llular growth models. 
One reason is that growth models must deal with role=
 differentiation
without explicit coordinates.  Therefore, they need to est=
ablish a
system of signaling that fills the same purpose, which would then
=
require more information to encode than simply encoding the shape
itself.  =
Along these lines, I have rarely seen a cellular growth model
produce anyth=
ing more than a blob or an amorphous shape without clear
parts.  However, o=
f course, more rigorous comparisons would certainly
be interesting.  

Abou=
t the skin issue, in what sense do you think first motifs of skin
would "fa=
il?"  It seems that the main problem is really to design a
world in which s=
kin is useful.  If it was anything like the real
world, it would allow for =
a large diversity of body covers that could
range from simple cell walls to=
 full-fledged human skin, which would
allow a gradual complexification of t=
he skin motif.  But barring a
simulation of all of physics, what would skin=
 be for?

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_che=
rvenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi all, 
> 
> I agree with Ken that regularities ar=
e preserved and elaborated 
> during evolution (actually in the case of com=
plexification). But 
> there is another question. Can we compare the genoty=
pe complexity for 
> both models, what if the CPPN encodes a very complex f=
unction with 
> many dimentions and the other method that produces the same=
 results 
> has less genes? I don't see any info about genotype complexity =
on 
> Picbreeder. And because most of the interesting pictures have very 
>=
 long lineages, probably the mutation rates are high too, it is 
> possible=
 that these examples have very complex genomes. More complex 
> than it cou=
ld be done with another method, cellurar growth for 
> example. Consider th=
e square shape that Robert evolved. For a human's 
> perception it is very =
simple but there may be about hundreds of 
> connections in the CPPN. 
> 
>=
 By the way we should make difference between CPPN output images, when 
> w=
e concern *bodies*. Because in the physics sense, a CPPN can easily 
> crea=
te hundreds of separate objects in one snapshot. There is a 
> difference b=
etween the raw CPPN snapshot and a physical body in the 
> sense we want it=
 to be. If I say "here is an apple" I usually mean 
> one object. But a CPP=
N with structure capturing a repetition 
> regularity can make infinite num=
ber of apples. 
> 
> Another thing I'd like to discuss is how does it fit i=
nto the fitness 
> search. Suppose we need to evolve a "creature" with a sk=
in preserving 
> the inner body intact. I really believe that all first mot=
ifs of skin 
> will fail. But on the other hand, Novelty Search would searc=
h too 
> vast space before it ever finds the right motif. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> =
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > J=
eff, that's a good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There
> > are =
many considerations, and although I may not hit all of them, I
> > think in=
 general it can be refuted:
> > 
> > Generally, I think HyperNEAT (i.e. NEA=
T with CPPNs) already
> > approximately follow the scenario that you outlin=
e:  It discovers 
> key
> > motifs (whether they be skin or something else)=
 early in evolution 
> and
> > then as the overall body plan is deformed, t=
he original motifs are
> > often preserved (which again includes skin).  Th=
e main idea is that
> > skin is like a kind of surrounding motif for the ov=
erall shape, and 
> if
> > the pverall shape is warped through some kind of=
 mutation in the
> > internal CPPN, then however the shape is surrounded wi=
ll naturally
> > warp in the same way.
> > 
> > In fact, you can see this h=
appen consistently in Picbreeder.  It is
> > possible to consider the simpl=
e black outline of many of the color
> > figures as a "skin."  You can noti=
ce that it is special by noting 
> that
> > often the outer band is black b=
ut everything structure inside is
> > color.  Then, if the shape of the ove=
rall image warps, so does the
> > outer membrane.
> > 
> > However, you mig=
ht say that such a "skin" is not complex enough to 
> be
> > convincing.  P=
erhaps skin should have multiple parts, i.e. its own
> > special structure.=
  In fact, if you look closely, you can find many
> > such examples.  For e=
xample, there are often double-layer outer
> > membranes that form, such as=
 in this image:
> > 
> > http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D=
317
> > 
> > There is a clear outer structure that surrounds the complex 
>=
 curvature
> > of the object.
> > 
> > Or, perhaps more interestingly, you =
can get several layers of color
> > bands, but only on the outer membrane, =
such as in this image that 
> ends
> > in a light blue that becomes green, =
then becomes yellow, before
> > sinking into the inner-body color of orange=
:
> > 
> > http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D4227
> > 
> > =
To show that the outer membrane warps easily and naturally 
> regardless
> =
> of shape changes (even complex ones), I further evolved that image 
> to
=
> > get a new shape, and you can see that the outer membrane has the 
> sam=
e
> > motif nevertheless, nicely warped to accommodate the new overall 
> s=
hape:
> > 
> > http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D5635
> > 
=
> > It is also important to note that outer membranes in nature are not
> >=
 uniform covers and often transition into something else on the
> > surface=
.  For example, consider lips and eyes.  Or perhaps even more
> > important=
ly, consider fingernails, where the outer cover actually
> > falls *under* =
something else (i.e. the nail), violating the covering
> > rule.  I point t=
hese exceptions out because in Picbreeder you also
> > often see almost con=
sistent outer motifs that are broken in a couple
> > places.  While these l=
ocations often are arbitrary, the point is 
> that
> > such a capability co=
uld be exploited if it actually mattered.
> > 
> > Moving from 2-D to 3-D s=
hould not matter in the case of skin, just 
> as
> > moving CPPNs from 2-D =
to 4-D continues to allow all the same
> > regularities.  So when you see e=
xamples in 2-D, they are also 
> possible
> > in 3-D for the same reasons.
=
> > 
> > Most of these outer skin motifs can arise early when the shape is
=
> > simple and are then easily preserved.  However, they are not always
> >=
 preserved.  For example, the multicolor skin above evolved into a
> > diff=
erent multicolor skin in one lineage:
> > 
> > http://picbreeder.org/search=
/showgenome.php?sid=3D4228
> > 
> > This phenomenon is expected from the an=
alogy with nature, just as
> > scales can evolve into fur, or fur into unco=
vered skin, all still
> > serving the role of outer membrane.
> > 
> > I th=
ink it's important to note that skin or an outer membrane is not
> > really=
 any different from any other CPPN-generated motif, in that it
> > can be p=
reserved, warped, or changed in its internal structure.  So 
> I
> > don't =
think there is really anything special going on in the 
> argument
> > comp=
ared to the discovery of symmetry or other conventions.
> > 
> > ken 
> > 
=
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> > >
> > > He=
llo all-
> > > 
> > > Ken has challenged us all many times to think about w=
hether there 
> is any
> > > need for a process of development. The identit=
y of cells in
> > developmental
> > > processes is determined by local cont=
extual information whereas 
> Ken
> > > advocates skipping that by letting =
cells determine their identity
> > via giving
> > > them their objective co=
ordinates. The question is whether we lose
> > anything
> > > important to =
the evolution of complexity by skipping this step.
> > > 
> > > I think it =
is a fascinating question and, unable to come up with 
> a good
> > > reaso=
n why development matters myself, but wanting to give the
> > argument a
> =
> > rigorous evaluation, I have been asking many people in our field 
> whe=
ther
> > > they can describe something unique that a developmental process
=
> > provides. No
> > > one has come up with  a reason that compels me, so I=
 have become a
> > strong
> > > advocate of the lack of a need for an unfol=
ding process.
> > > 
> > > However, in the course of watching a keynote on =
development in 
> natural
> > > systems at this year's gecco, an argument i=
n favor of development
> > occurred
> > > to me that may have merit. I am i=
nterested to hear what y'all 
> think
> > of it.
> > > 
> > > The argument =
is this: it might be easier to evolve certain large-
> scale
> > > properti=
es when the organism is simple and small and then 
> scale/grow
> > them
> =
> > up, rather than incorporating them into an already complex 
> phenotype=
. I
> > > think an example illustrates the point best. Imagine evolution
> =
> figuring out
> > > how to put a coat of skin on an organism. It is not th=
at hard to
> > figure out
> > > what the shape of that skin should be when =
the embryo has only a 
> few
> > cells.
> > > Once that simple and small co=
at of skin has formed, it can follow
> > the simple
> > > rule of keeping t=
he layer of skin the same thickness, and adding 
> cells
> > > within that =
layer to grow to cover any arbitrary shape that the
> > phenotype
> > > bec=
omes. This simple rule could produce a skin shell for a bat or 
> a
> > jag=
uar.
> > > Now consider how hard it would be for 3D hyperneat to create a 
=
> skin
> > shell
> > > for a bat or a jaguar. The mathematical function to =
create such
> > outlines is
> > > very complex (although it is less so if i=
t is a composition of 
> other,
> > > already created functions that produc=
ed the rest of the body). 
> Still, it
> > > seems that this task might be =
harder for hyperneat than following
> > the simple
> > > developmental rule=
s outlined above.
> > > 
> > > What do you think? I would happily be convin=
ced that this 
> argument is
> > > without merit, so please let me know if =
you see any problems with 
> it.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Cheers,
> > > Jeff Clu=
ne
